properties.name: 18th & Alder trolley carbarn collapses into Tanner Creek Sewer (March 18, 1904)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes SW 18th & AlderThe Multnomah Street Railway Co. built this trolley carbarn at 18th & Alder in 1891. In March of 1904 heavy rains caused the Tanner Creek sewer, of shoddy construction with little or no mortar holding the bricks together, to collapse. Debris began to clog the sewer and cause underground flooding. Finally, at 5:00 p.m. on March 18th the entire Alder Street carbarn collapsed into the ground (a giant sink hole), taking ten "open" trolleys (note the lack of siding) 20 feet below the street with it. All but 2 or so cars were successfully salvaged.

properties.name: Agricultural Palace (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Alberta Line (1903-1949)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesPortland Railway Co. initated the Alberta Line (1903-1949), running from a downtown loop of 2nd-Morrison-3rd-Washington out to its terminus at N.E. Alberta and 25th. By 1909, the line had been extended in spurts to N.E. 30th at Ainsworth. Converted to bus in 1949.

properties.name: American Inn (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes The 3-story American Inn was built by the Exposition for the Exposition, and was the only hotel located inside the Expo\'s grounds. It sat at the western edge of the grounds. The rates were fixed by the Expo for the duration of the Fair (price-gouging was a concern). The Inn is seen here on the "shores" of Guild\'s Lake, around the southern half of which the Expo was centered. I say "shores" because Guild\'s Lake was really more akin to, say, Oak\'s Bottom, than an actual lake. Prior to the selection of Guild\'s Lake as the location for the Expo, there were concerns that the lake would completely dry up over the summer, but it was revealed that the lake kept a healthly 2 feet even in the dryest, hottest months.

properties.name: Bell Rose Interurban No. 1006 departs Water Street Yards.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBell Rose No. 1006, a 1907 American Car Co. Brill "Yellow Jacket," leaves the Water Street Yards. This trolley is approximately where the Darigold Dairy is today. In the background you can see the Grand Avenue viaduct. Several lines continued south all the way to Oregon City (and Oaks Park, of course). I think that staircase on viaduct is the one up near Caruthers street. This photo is from the 1940s, at the earliest. By this time the smaller city trolley lines had been almost entirely discontinued, and although interurban service to Oregon City continued to do decent business, the interurban line to Gresham was shorted to to the Bell Rose stop.

properties.name: Blue Mouse Theatre (1912-1958)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Opened in 1912 as the Globe Theatre, then remodeled and reopened in 1921 as the Blue Mouse. The building was sold in 1958 and demolished. Paul Forsythe, who had bought the theatre in 1940, took the sign with him in \'58 and installed it on the old Capitol Theatre building.

properties.name: Boss Saloon (1870-1940s)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesEast end of NW GlisanThe Boss Saloon was originally a waiting room for the river ferry that ran from Flanders street on the west side to current eastern base of the Steel Bridge. The ferry was abandoned in 1888 when the first Steel Bridge was completed. The building was a two-story "flatiron" building: triangular with three sides. It became a saloon and purportedly was a hotbed for shanghai-ing shennigans. It became a simple eatery, "Boss Lunch" in its later years. I\'m sure it was demolised in the 1940s to make way for Harbor Drive (which is Waterfront Park today).

properties.name: Bottom of Portland Cablecar Trestle, & Powerhouse (1890-1904).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.W. 18th Ave. & Mill Street.The base of the Portland Heights cable-car trestle, where the powerhouse which ran the cable was also situated. The trestle was 1,040 feet long and climbed at a 20.93% grade (roughly 20 feet vertical for every 100 feet horizontal). The trestle was discontinued in 1904 with the completion of the Vista Bridge. I\'m not sure when it was actually torn down, tho\' I have to assume it didn\'t last long.

properties.name: Bridge Transfer Line (1915-1948)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesInitiated in 1915 by merging parts of the existing Russell-Shaver and East Side Lines. Operated from northern terminus around N. Larrabee and Mississippi, down Union and Grand Aves. to SE Woodward & 10th. In 1937 conversion of the line to trolley bus began, but rationing and shortages due to WWII saw return of the trolleys, including the chipping out of paved-over tracks in some areas in 1941. The line was converted to buses permanently in 1948. A large section of narrow gauge tracks from this line can still be seen today under the Grand Ave. Viaduct.

properties.name: Broadway Line (1903-1948)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesN.E. 29th Avenue and Mason Street.From 1903 t0 1913 this line crossed the Burnside bridge and used a loop of Burnside-5th-Washington-3rd as its eastern terminus. In 1913 the line was re-routed across the brand new Broadway Bridge and terminated at Broadway and Jefferson instead. The last line to receive new trolleys in 1932. Line converted to gas bus in 1948.

properties.name: Brooklyn Line (1903-1927)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThe City & Suburban Railway Company commenced service in 1903. The line\'s western terminus was a downtown loop between 3rd and 1st Streets, from whence it crossed the Morrison Bridge, turned south on Grand, then southeast on Woodward and Powell before reaching its southeastern terminus at 21st and Bush. The Powell & Bush legs of the line were folded into Bridge Transfer Line in 1927.

properties.name: Brooklyn Roundhouse.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt 1912, existing structure built during WWII, original brick structure demolished 1956. Home of three restored steam-powered locomotives (all owned by the City of Portland): the Southern Pacific 4449; the Spokane Portland & Seattle 700; and the Oregon Railroad & Navigation 197. The Roundhouse is owned by Union Pacific and leased by the City. The Oregon Rail Historical Foundation warns that the Roundhouse is a locked structure in the middle of an active intermodal facility, which is private Union Pacific property. There are no accessible roads or sidewalks nearby, tours are not regularly held due to liability concerns and workplace conditions. The UP Police regularly patrol the area since their office is a short distance away from the Roundhouse, and ask that you do not trespass, and respect the railroad\'s property. Trespassers can be fined, imprisioned, or both. The ORHF\'s long-term plan is to obtain the stretch of tracks to the east of OMSI, and built a permanent museum there so people can actually come and look at the engines.

properties.name: Brooklyn-Gideon Pedestrian Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Burkhard Building (1894-1934)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt 1894. Home to a dance hall & other businesses, in 1908 upper floors converted to hotel, & building renamed the Arcade Hotel after widening of Burnside in 1928/1929. It was torn down in 1934. Today: Convention Auto Wholesale. Be sure to check out Dan Haneckow\'s excellent research on the Burnside Arcades (see related website link).

properties.name: Capitol Theatre (1928-1977)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes A theatre with a capacity of 850 decorated in a Spanish motif. When the original Blue Mouse over on 10th closed in 1958 Paul Forsythe brought the Blue Mouse sign over and put it on the Capitol Theatre\'s marquee. The entire block was levelled for a parking structure in 1977. That building, along with the Corbett building, if I\'m right, were levelled in 1988 or so to make way for the Pioneer Place mall and Pioneer tower, and (more recently) the Piorneer Rotunda.

properties.name: Carnival of Venice (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Produced by the world-famous Bolossy Kiralfy, the Carnival of Venice at the 1905 Lewis & Clark Expo featured a 300 member cast performing dance, song & skit on a 400-foot set complete w/ gondalas, including European ballerinas & the Metropolitan Opera Company.

properties.name: Chamber of Commerce Building (1892-1934)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesHailed as the NW\'s premiere office space (love that circa 1890-1910 Portland boosterism!), the Commerce Building (as it was called in later days) boasted the aforementioned banks, an auditorium, "the prestigious Commercial Club," a bowling alley, saloons, & a billiard room. In 1906 NYLife sold the building to the Spokane Portland & Seattle Railroad. A few years later, deeming the Commerce Building "too old fashioned" the SP&S then its local offices to the newer American Bank Building (completed in 1913). In the shadow of the Great Depression, SP&S, citing the tax & maintenance costs, & claiming that a remodel would be "too expensive & impractical," had the building demolished in 1934. The lot was used, & is still used, as a parking lot.

properties.name: Chinese Shanties (c.1905).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.W. 18th & Salmon Chinese hamlet and gardens in approximate vicinity of S.W. 18th & Salmon, circa 1905.

properties.name: Corbett Building (1907-1988)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesSW 5th & MorrisonThe 10-floor Corbett building opened in 1907. On May 1, 1988 it was demolished to make way for the Pioneer Place project.

properties.name: Corner of SE Clinton and Kenilworth Ave.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBefore SE 28th Place, there was Kenilworth Avenue. Don\'t know when the name change was made but "Kenilworth" appears on a few trolley system maps in the 1920s.

properties.name: Corner of SE Francis and Kenilworth Ave.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesAnother sidewalk marking of the original name of SE 28th Place. The Woodstock trolley line used to connect between Powell Blvd. and Gladstone on Kenilworth.

properties.name: Depot-Morrison Line (1907-1923).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesN.W. 27th Avenue & Thurman Street.The amalganization of numerous pre-existing lines. Expanded up to Thurman & Upshur streets in 1904 in anticipation of the hordes of vistors to the 1905 Lewis & Clark Exposition. Steps for ease of access to the trolleys were even built along the line. Folded into the Willamette Heights Line in 1923. In the photo, a Depot-Morrison trolley navigates a track switch at S.W. 5th & Morrison, circa 1915.

properties.name: East Ankeny trolley barn.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.E. Ankeny between 26th & 28th Avenues. Before the Great Depression Portland had the nations third largest narrow-gauge street car system. These trolleys had to go somewhere night, in form of large garages called "car barns." As best as I can figure SE Ankeny between 26th Ave. & 28th Ave. was the location of the East Ankeny trolley barn. Continued to be used as a bus barn until at least the late \'40s / early \'50s.

properties.name: Eastmoreland Line (1912-1926)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Elk Rock Tunnel north entrance.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesSomehwere very close to here is the north portal of the Elk Rock Tunnel, I\'m not positive of an exact locaiton. The tunnel was built for use by the Red Electric passenger line in 1921.

properties.name: Elk Rock Tunnel south entrance
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesElk Rock Tunnel south entranceSomehwere very close to here is the south portal of the Elk Rock Tunnel, I\'m not positive of an exact locaiton. The tunnel was built for use by the Red Electric passenger line in 1921.

properties.name: Elk Rock train trestle (1888-1921)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesElk RockReplaced by the Elk Rock train tunnel in 1921, for use by Southern Pacific\'s Red Electric passenger line. [appoximate location]

properties.name: Errol Heights Line (1913-1926)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Festival Hall & Auditorium (1905)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNW 25th north of WilsonThe Festival Hall was 305\' long by 125\' wide with a seating capacity of 2,500. The stage alone was 75 feet wide with space for 500 people. The hall has a seating capacity of 2,500. The stage is seventy-five feet in width and will accommodate 500 people. All the large musical festivals and conventions were held here. I suspect the picture here is only a conceptual sketch, and that the final building may have appeared different...

properties.name: Former PDX Trolley.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNow a joke shop!

properties.name: Hal's Tavern.
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes For what its worth, the best shuffleboard table in PDX. Waxed daily!!

properties.name: Haunted Castle (1905).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Part of "the Trail," the concourse of more amusement park-esque entertainments at the 1905 Expo, which one walked down before crossing the Bridge of Nations out to the Federal Exhibit in the middle of Guilds Lake. Scary, I guess. No one else seemed to think so (the Trail was a failure financially).

properties.name: Hawthorne Line (1889-1936)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThis early steam-dummy line originally running east-west on Hawthorne from Grand to 54rd was expanded (and, of course, electrified by 1893) to run from the Alder Street loop (Madison-2nd-Alder-3rd) out to SE 74th & Woodward. Converted to electric bus in 1936, which in turn were converted to gasoline buses in 1949.

properties.name: Irvington-Jefferson Line (1890-1938)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesN.E. 15th Avenue and Prescott StreetThe Jefferson and Irvington lines, each older lines dating back to 1890, were merged in 1914 by PRL&P in 1914. The line ran from an western terminus at S.W. Jefferson and 18th to 5th, then north across the Steel Bridge. From there it jogged east on Holladay and Multnomah to 15th, where it continued north to its western terminus at Prescott. The entire Jefferson leg was discontinued in 1933, and the line was once again the "Irvington" line. This, in turn, was converted to autobus in 1938.

properties.name: Ladd & Tilton Bank (1868-1954)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt in 1868. Demolished in 1954. Today, a parking lot.

properties.name: Lafayette Pedestrian Bridge.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThis rad industrial pedestrian bridge over the Brooklyn SP Rail Yards may not be long for this world. Persistant rumors allude to its demolition, and to be fair, some the plank floor boards seem quite wobbly.

properties.name: Laurelhurst, the Addition with Character
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesOne of the secrets of the expansion of Portland\'s trolley system c.1900-1920 was real estate development. For example, when service began to Gresham it was a hamlet of 100 souls. A year later 1,000 people lived there. Mind you these are electric trolleys, so they bring more than a fast way to get from A to B, but light (yesteryear\'s Portland Railway Light and Power Company, today\'s PGE) and power… MODERNITY through ELECTRIFICATION ! ! Laurelhurst is no exception. This advert for the "Addition with Character" is patently false, at least in the sense that no trolley rode north-south on 39th Avenue. The Montaville Line passed in front of the Laurelhurst "gates" on Glisan, but never passed through them.

properties.name: Lewis & Clark Centennial Exposition Fire Department
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNW 26th & VaughnThe Expo had its own fire department for the duration of the fair.

properties.name: Lewis & Flanders Building (1869-1940)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesUntil the 1890s home of a farm & industrial equipment company, then a dry goods wholesaler. Demolished in 1940. The Fire Station on site was built in 1951.

properties.name: Liberty Temple (1918-1920)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes6th & YamhillBuilt in 3 days in March of 1918 as headquarters and staging area for War Bond drives. It should be emphasized that the Temple is clearly IN THE STREET, as is, not built on an empty lot. Instead, its snuggled up against the S.E. corner of the Hotel Portland (the building on the right), so it seems the Temple came out to about the middle of the street. It should come as no surprise that with the end of the war the Temple was moved to Salmon and Park in 1919. It was torn down the next year.

properties.name: Liberty Theatre (1921-2004).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  Built in 1921. Ceased operations in 1960 and was converted to generic commercial space used by a dollar store, which moved out in 1991, after Clackamas County purchased the building in 1990. The County used the main floor for records storage and rented the upper level as offices. The building leaked badly, however, eventually forcing the office tenants to leave due to bad air quality, and the building was simply to damp to store County records. Demolished in March of 2004.

properties.name: Little Psychic Shop Building (c.1910-2006)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Formerly located at 2008 SE 11th.

properties.name: Loewenberg-Leadbetter Mansion (1894-1960)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes   Built 1894 by capitalist Julius Loewenberg, later owned by the Leadbetters. Donated to Oregon Historical Society in 1951 and used as a museum \'til 1954. Demolished in 1960. Apartments today.

properties.name: Lutz Tavern.
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Main Entrance to the 1905 Lewis & Clark Centennial Exposition.
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  NW 26th & UpshurThe main entrance to the 1905 Lewis & Clark Centennial and American Pacific Exposition and Oriental Fair was here, at NW 26th & Upshur, which at the time was the northern edge of town. Trolleys, running on tracks built specifically to bring the 2,554,848 vistors to the Expo from downtown and Union Depot. This photo is looking southeast towards the gates. I assume those are guards on top of the little buildings there. The picture is striking due to the mass of people and trolleys parked bumper to bumper to move them.

properties.name: Merchants Hotel (1885)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes The Merchants Hotel started out as a hotel in 1885, but has also hosued a dance hall, a cracker factory, a billiards room, and a bar, plus apartments for single ladies w/ "friends in the fleet." After the Great War, it housed a complex of several Japanese professional offices, a Japanese grocer, and the editorial offices of Japanese Oregon Weekly.

properties.name: Milwaukie Museum
properties.description: Posted by System  3737 Southeast Adams Street, Portland, OR, 97222Milwaukie Museum

properties.name: Monte Carlo Building (c.1910 - January 20, 2002)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesLocation of the Monte Cristo & Lido restaurants before they burned down on January 20, 2002. The block, built by italian immigrants, also housed a large market place.

properties.name: Moreland Theatre (1926).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  6712 Southeast Milwaukie Avenue, Portland, OR, 97202The 675-seat Moreland Theatre opened as a vaudeville venue in 1926. Retaining its original name, it has operated as a theater ever since, although it switched to cinema in the 1930s. (503) 236-9500

properties.name: Mt. Tabor Car #438 near 57th & Belmont.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThe "S-S" on the front of the car stands for "Sunnyside Line," which serviced Belmont street but I think didn\'t actually run all way out to the end of the Tabor Line at SE 88th Ave. (perhaps only as far as 69th). The Massachusetts House in the background was moved to this location from the 1905 Lewis & Clark Exposition. If I recall correctly, the only remaining structure from that Expo is now part of a movie theater in St. Johns, so I\'m going to go out on a limb and say the Massachusetts House didn\'t make it for much longer (L&C Expo buildings weren\'t really built to last). Car 438 was a 1907 narrow guage (42") American Car Co. "Class K" trolley. It was approximately 48\' long and 8\' wide, had 38 seats and could carry up to 87 passangers standing room only. Between 1923 and 1926 twenty-five of the 38 Class K Cars were converted to "Class L" with the addition of two additional GE-58 motors.

properties.name: Mt. Tabor Crater Amphitheatre
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Mt. Tabor Trolley No. 52 Jumps Track, Kills Four (1897)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.E. 7th Avenue & Morrison StreetOn April 28, 1897, Car No. 52 of the Mt. Tabor Line (operated by the City & Suburban Railway Co.), was crossing the E. Morrison St. trestle spanning the slough located at modern-day 7th Avenue. The Pullman-model electric streetcar was going too fast when it hit the track split on or near the trestle, and jumped off the tracks, subsequently crashing through the trestle\'s guardrails, and fell into to the slough below belly-side up. Three passengers were killed in the crash, and a fourth died later resulting from injuries sustained in the crash.

properties.name: Near the top of the Portland Heights Cablecar Trestle during construction (c.1889 ?)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNear the top of the Portland Heights Line cablecar trestle during construction.

properties.name: No. 539 E. Ankeny-Bound at 2nd & SW Morrison.
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Based on the automobiles I\'d put this photo in the early- to mid-1930s. Car 539 was one of the 145 "Pay-As-You-Enter" (PAYE) Class K American Car Co. cars the Portland Traction Company purchased between 1909 and 1911, making the Class Ks the flagships of the heyday of Portland\'s trolley age. If you saw a trolley from 1910-1920, it would be a Class K. The East Ankeny 539 is seen here on Morrison and 2nd (or thereabouts). In the background you can see the old Capitol Theatre at 4th & Morrison, and behind it the back of the Corbett Building (the tall one).

properties.name: Oak's Park Museum?
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes I guess the website\'s been changed/updated, but it used to boast that there was an "Oaks Park Museum" somewhere on the property, owhich included a lamp from the 1905 L&C centennial Expo. I visited late spring/early summer (to try and figure out if any original 1905 or same era buildings were still around) and this little building on the south of the property was the only thing which looked like it might house a "museum." That said, peering through the window, it didn\'t look like much and it didn\'t look like it had been used much (the windows were dirty, there was yard debris around and on the building, etc.). Too bad, because I wish there were more little museums here and there...

properties.name: Old Bridge Transfer Line trolley tracks.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesSE Grand & Ivon St.Remnants of the Bridge Transfer Line trolley tracks under the Grand Ave. Viaduct. The viaduct was completed c.1930, and the BT Line largely discontinued on and off again until 10 years later. The Viaduct is currently scheduled for heavy remodelling/reconstruction, and I suspect these tracks will either be paved over or torn up.

properties.name: Old trolley tracks under Hawthorne viaduct.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThese tracks clearly are coming from the Hawthorne bridge, then curve south. Not really sure which line these one\'s would have been. They could be old Montaville (Hawthorne) tracks, which used a wider guage than the old Bridge Transfer line, but then I don\'t see why they would curve south. I would guess these might be old Oregon City Interurban tracks, which was, after all, the last of the old electric trains to stop service.

properties.name: Oregon City Interurban 1097 in downtown Oregon City (c.1931).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  A tandem interurban electric makes it way through downtown Oregon City, c. 1931. The Liberty Theater in the background was built in 1921 and demolished in March of 2004.

properties.name: Oriental Exhibits Palace (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes NW Vaughn between 27th & 28th At a cost of 5,425, the 308\'x160\' Oriental Exhibits Palace was one of the first Exposition buildings to be completed. Although 20 nations from east Asia and the middle east shared the building, over half the floorspace was dedicated to Japanese exhibit. Costing over million dollars, the Japanese Emperor was not content with a perceived poor showing at the Louisiana Purchase Expo in St. Louis the previous year, and spared to expense to tout the rise of Japan at the 1905 edition (Japan had, after all, just decisively destroyed the Russian fleet at Tsushima that March).

properties.name: Oriental Theatre (1927 -1970)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes "Where the Sound is Better." Absolutely lavish theatre (playhouse, not movies) built in 1927 with a seating capacity of 2,038. Never really viable as a movie house and demolished in 1970. The interiors were auctioned off prior to demolition, and I think I read somewhere that several pieces are in an existing theatre elsewhere in Oregon (Astoria?). Oh, its a parking lot today.

properties.name: Perkins Hotel (1891-1962)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Built 1891. 125 Rooms. Remodeled 1908. Demolished 1962. Not sure which corner this building was actually on, but think its the NE one since that building\'s construction date is approx. 1965. Other three corners are pre-1962.

properties.name: Prof. Barnes' Educated Horse & Diving Elk
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  Part of "the Trail," the concourse of more amusement park-esque entertainments at the 1905 Expo, which one walked down before crossing the Bridge of Nations out to the Federal Exhibit in the middle of Guilds Lake. Two elk with 8 years of experience dove headfirst 40-feet into a tank of water. Prof. Barnes\'s horse, "Trixie," demonstrated an understanding of the English language & basic arithmetic.

properties.name: Red Electric Eastside Loop: Oswego Station (1914-1929)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesState Street & A This is where Southern Pacific\'s Red Electric passenger line stopped on its Eastside Loop in then what was plain ol\' "Oswego."

properties.name: Replica of the Willamette Meteor.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesOriginally discovered in 1902 by Ellis Hughs. The largest meteor ever discovered in the U.S. Hughs, w/ the help of his teenage son & an old horse, physically labored for 3 months to move the 15.5 ton meteorite 3/4 of a mile off property owned by the Oregon Iron & Steel Company to his own land. The con failed and Oregon Iron & Steel took possession of the meteor, displaying at the 1905 Lewis & Clark Expo, then selling it to a Mr. William Dodge for 0,600, who subsequently donated it to the Museum of Natural History in New York, where it remains to this day.

properties.name: Richmond Line (1888-1936)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.E. 41st Avenue & Clinton Street.The Richmond Trolley service terminus was at 42nd (or so) and Clinton from 1890 (when the line was upgraded from horse-drawn trolleys to electrification) until the line was discontinued in 1936.

properties.name: S. Chirstofferson Flies Biplane off Multnomah Hotel (June 11, 1912)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes SW 4th & AshOn June 11, 1912, Silas Christofferson flew from the roof of Portland\'s Multnomah Hotel across the Willamette and Columbia rivers to Pearson Field in Vancouver in his 40-horsepwer-engine biplane in 12 minutes.

properties.name: Schooner on the Willamette
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes

properties.name: Sellwood Trolley Administrative Offices.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt 1905. Administrative office for the PRL&P Co. Renovated into office spaces.

properties.name: Sellwood Trolley Barn (1905-2005).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt in 1905. The cars of the Sellwood, Eastmoreland, and Errol Heights Lines. Also where you transferred on to the Estacada and Cazadero Interurban lines. This was the last standing trolley barn in Portland, and would have qualified for Portland\'s registry of historic buildings. The property was donated to Reed College, and then the plastics company went into bankruptcy. Assessment revealed hydraulic oil, toluene, and lead under the building and in the soil, as well as substantial amounts of asbestos in the building itself. The property was sold, cleaned, and finally demolished in 2005. The east-facing original wall has been left standing.

properties.name: Sellwood Trolley Powerstation.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesTrolley powerstation constructed in in 1905 by Oregon Water, Power & Railway Company, which consolidate with Portland Railway to become the almighly Portland Railway, Light and Power Co. in 1906 (which would eventualy become PGE). Simutaneously or subsequently the cavernous Sellwood Trolley Barn was constructed across the street, and a office/motorman\'s clubhouse beyond that. The barn was demolished in 2005 to make way for a massive subdivision. The offices have been renovated and are still offices today.

properties.name: Siberian Railway (1905).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  A TRIP TO SIBERIA! proclaims the front. "RUSSIA LOSES WAR TO JAPAN!" people joke as they keep thier money and move along to the Federal Exhibit Building... Part of "the Trail," the concourse of more amusement park-esque entertainments at the 1905 Expo, which one walked down before crossing the Bridge of Nations out to the Federal Exhibit in the middle of Guilds Lake.

properties.name: St. Johns Line (1888-1937)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesIn late 1888 the Willamette Bridge Railway Co. began a short steam-motor line which ran from a northern terminus at Burlington Street in St. Johns to Stanton & Commercial in the town of Albina. In 1903 the City & Suburban Railway Company electrified the line and extended service into downtown. Line converted to trolley bus April 11, 1937. The gas ones followed in 1958.

properties.name: Sunnyside Trolley No. 656 at 33rd & Belmont (c.1915)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesTrolley 656 stopped at 33rd and Belmont, circa 1915. The buildings on the left are Zupans today. What impresses me is that it the entire block of buildings on the right is still intact today (Laughing Planet, Aalto, Stumptown, et al.).

properties.name: Swan Island Airport (1927-1935).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesPortland\'s first airport. The Port of Portland purchased Swan Island in 1925 and began construct. Charles Lindberg(!) flew out and dedicated the field in 1927. Full service began in 1930. By 1935 it was determined it was too small of a sight for increased traffic.

properties.name: Temple of Mirth (1905).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  Part of "the Trail," the concourse of more amusement park-esque entertainments at the 1905 Expo, which one walked down before crossing the Bridge of Nations out to the Federal Exhibit in the middle of Guilds Lake. I have no idea what was in, or what comprises, a "Temple of Mirth," but I assume its supposed to make you laugh. And the building\'s a bit creepy.

properties.name: The Bathhouse at the Oaks (1905 - 1920s?)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  The Oaks, on the east bank of the WillametteThe tank of this bathhouse was actually submerged in the Willamette with slats that let the river\'s current pass through for hygenienic purposes ("fresh water all the time!!") This became a harder selling point into the 1920s as people became a bit more aware of pollution.

properties.name: The Chutes at the Lewis & Clark Expo (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes The 1905 Lewis & Clark Exposition wasn\'t all serious exhibits of nations, states, and trades! You could ride the Chutes! Just like a real logger!! Fun!!! Have no info to actually back this up but the Chutes may have been moved, or at least parts of it moved, to the Oaks Amusement Park after the Expo (the Oaks opened two days before the Expo, and many materials and rides were purchased by the Oaks after the Expo closed).

properties.name: The Chutes at the Oaks (1905 - ???)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes The Oaks, on the east bank of the Willamette

properties.name: The Hotel Portland (1890-1951)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Opened 1890. I\'ve read that the fairly glam Hotel Portland was responsible for shifiting Portland\'s cultural scene and nightllife away "Old Town" to Broadway. Flirted with expansion plans around 1910. Poor construction in the foundations led to detioration and eventual closing. Demolished 1951. Parking garage until 1980s. Today: Pioneer Sqaure.

properties.name: The Marquam Grand (1891-1912)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt 1891. Opera house/theatre. Collapsed on its own power, rather spectacularly, in 1912. What hadn\'t collapsed was demolished shortly after. Cafe Unknown (see related website link) tells the story better.

properties.name: The Massachusetts Building (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  NW Upshur & 27thThe state of Massachusetts\' submission to the 1905 Lewis & Clark Centennial Exposition, the building\'s front was an exact reproduction of the Beacon Hill Statehouse in Boston, the first floor a replica of the Senate chamber of the old Statehouse in Boston, and the second floor patterned in the newer State Senate chamber. When the Exposition was over it was purchased and relocated to roughly SE Belmont and 66th where it was used as a sanitarium until 1910 when then President of the Portland Rail Light & Power (think PGE+TriMet) purchased it and had it converted into stately Josselyn Hall.

properties.name: The Massachusetts House (1905-1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes-from Venerable Properties- "The building was built for the Lewis & Clark Centennial Exposition. When the Expo was over, the building was moved to the east side of Portland and became part of the Crystal Springs Sanitarium. In 1910, the Sanitarium sold its holdings and Bennage Josselyn, president of the Portland Railway Light and Power Co., bought the building and several acres. Josselyn had the building remodeled into a residence, which he named Josselyn Hall. The home became vacant in the 1930s. Today, it\'s a residential area."

properties.name: The Oregonian Building (1892-1950s)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThe first steel-frame building in the western U.S. 9 stories tall, with an extra 4 counting the clock tower, for a total height of 203 feet, the tallest tower in Oregon when completed. KGW made its first radio broadcast from this building in 1922. The tower may have been demolished in the 1940s, and the rest of the building followed in the \'50s.

properties.name: The Orpheum Theatre (1925-1954)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes The Orpheum was originally the Empress Theatre, which dates back at least to the mid-\'teens, and the Empress may have been the Pantages before that. Demolished 1954. Now Nordstroms!

properties.name: The Public Service Building (1928).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNote the neon signs at the very top. The words "Power" "Heat" "Light" and "Gas" pointed in each cardinal direction. Home of the Portland Railway, Light and Power Company as it began to move away from trolleys and towards becoming today\'s PGE.

properties.name: The Streets of Cairo (1905).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesPart of "the Trail," the concourse of more amusement park-esque entertainments at the 1905 Expo, which one walked down before crossing the Bridge of Nations out to the Federal Exhibit in the middle of Guilds Lake (the Trail was built on pylons over Guilds Lake). Other than the mammoth "Carnival of Venice," the Streets of Cairo amusement was the biggest on the Trail in terms of floorspace. By passing through it I think you could get the nearby Chutes. This & a lot of the exhibits & entertainments at the 1905 Expo sum up to a sort of proto-Epcot Center. At least here you could get a Turkish coffee (presumably).

properties.name: The Tavern at the Oaks (1905 - Prohibition).
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes  The Oaks, on the east bank of the Willamette.Bottle of Weinhards for 5 cents!

properties.name: The Whirl at the Oaks (1906 - ???)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes You rode in the little gondolas and it spun you around over the Willamette. Fun!

properties.name: The oldest building on Front Street?
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes233 S.W. Front St., Portland, ORBuilt 1870.

properties.name: Top of Portland Cablecar Trestle (1896-1904).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.W. 18th Avenue & Clifton Street.A cable car (on its way downhill) a few blocks above the top of the Portland Heights Cablecar Trestle.

properties.name: Torn-Up Trolley Tracks.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.W. 5th & TaylorThe City was digging up Taylor and had to removed paved-over tracks at Fifth. Behold, the exavated bones of the city!!

properties.name: Train Turntable.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesTurntable for the Brooklyn Roundhouse.

properties.name: Transfer Point to Cablecar Trestle (1896-1904).
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesS.W. Jefferson & 18th Ave.Portland Traction Co. electrified the Portland Heights line in 1896, but continued to use cablecar trolleys to climb the 1,040 foot long trestle which ran from Mill to Elizabeth. From 1896 to 1904 passengers rode to Jefferson and 18th and transferred from electrical- to cable-car.

properties.name: Trolley Car Barn (Depot-Morrison Line)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesThe Depot-Morrison Line ran from 1892-1923. The trolley barn at 23rd & NE Savier was an ooold one, tho. Picture here is from late 1890s.

properties.name: Trolley Car No. 82 Jumps Tracks (June 21, 1903)
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroeseast approach to Burnside BridgePortland Railway Company Car No. 82 carrying 32 souls was coming up the eastern approach of the Burnside bridge from Woodlawn on June 21, 1903 when it jumped off the tracks and ran into a telephone pole. For the brave sacrifice of this pole a potential trajedy was averted, and only two ladies were merely shoken up. Thank you, telephone pole, THANK YOU!!

properties.name: Trolley Wreck (November 10, 1915)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesCar 649 had reached the end of its line to the south at 13th and Hall St. The crew disembarked to re-victual at an adjunct small grocery. While inside, Car 649\'s brakes failed (it had a history of such problems) and the car began to roll down the slope. Gradually picking up speed, Car 649 coasted 16 blocks north whereupon all 39,875 pounds of it smacked into Car 659 at Taylor street. From there, this unholy union of two trolleys continued another three blocks before hitting a third, unspecified trolley at the intersection of 11th & Morrison, bring this electrical trolley rampage to an end. Six humans were also injured.

properties.name: Trolley makes it way through intersection at Morrison & Grand (c.1930)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesLooking east up Morrison from Grand Ave. Up Morrison and to the right you can see the building that will some day become the Grand Central Bowling alley (the pointy squat tower on the NE corner of that building is the hint). It was originally the Grand Central Public Market.

properties.name: Trolley on the Hawthorne Bridge.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesTrolley Car No. 1102 departing downtown Portland.

properties.name: Willamette Shore Trolley Northern Terminus
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesSW Moody & BancroftCheck the website. You too!! Can ride a 1932 J.G. Brill Co. "Broadway" Trolley from SW Moody & Bancroft to downtown Lake Oswego (and back, if you want)!! Adult roundtrip tix are 0, one-way is ! Cross the 600\'+ Riverview Trestle!! Pass through the 1,396\' long Elk Rock Tunnel!! Maintained and Operated by the Oregon Electric Railway Historical Society. Check the website for details.

properties.name: Willamette Shore Trolley Southern Terminus
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesState & A, Lake OswegoCheck the website. You too!! Can ride a 1932 J.G. Brill Co. "Broadway" Trolley from downtown Lake Oswego to SW Moody & Bancroft (and back, if you want)!! Adult roundtrip tix are 0, one-way is ! Cross the 600\'+ Riverview Trestle!! Pass through the 1,396\' long Elk Rock Tunnel!! Maintained and Operated by the Oregon Electric Railway Historical Society. Check the website for details.

properties.name: Woodstock Trolley Barn (demolished)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesSE 26th & PowellThis wooden trolley carbarn & powerhouse was built in 1890 for the old Waverly-Woodstock line. The W-W was a response by eastside Portlanders to the electrification of other lines occuring downtown and up north in the Albina nieghborhood. As the small companies merged or were folded into larger and larger companies, ending with the PRL&P, the barn was used for storage of little-used equipment and trolleys. Cleveland High is peeking around the corner on the right. The tracks used to come down 26th and then jog to the southeast to 28th on what is now Kelton. I don\'t know when the barn was torn down.

properties.name: Woolworth's Sweet Shop.
properties.description: Posted by Tinzeroes Old wall advertisement.

properties.name: Worcester Building (1892-1941)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt in two sections in 1892, demolished 1941. The Police Dept. headquarters addition occupies/occupied part of the lot, the rest is parking.

properties.name: old Carver line trolley exposed track
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesPortland and Oregon Company Railway was incorporated by one Stephen Carver in 1913.1 Armed w/ 00,000 in capital, Carver dreamt of a street railway and interurban system capable of competing w/ existing monopolistic Portland trolley titan PRL&P. His vision involved exercising common-user rights to the existing tracks across the Hawthorne Bridge and tracks owned by the Clackamas Southern RR in Oregon City. Carver applied for franchises in Portland & Gladstone, while the backers of the Clackamas Southern applied for 1 in Oregon City. The Portland franchise was granted in October & Gladstone\'s in November. The Oregon City franchise was granted in Jan. of 1914, but included a clause requiring transfers be made available to the PRL&P Oregon City Interurban. Carver wouldn\'t have it & split from the Clackamas Southern group, which was sold to PRL&P shortly afterwards anyway. Undaunted, Carver altered his route to head south out of Portland then east along the south bank of the Clackamas River through Milwuakie up to the Viola area. Tracks originating at SE 3rd & Hawthorne wove through SE Portland, eventually running parallel to the SouthernPacific tracks out of town as far as, eventually, the new township of Carver.

properties.name: old Madison Street Bridge (1891-1910)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt by the Mt. Tabor Street Railway Co. Opened (as a toll bridge) in January, 1891, replacing an existing ferry at Jefferson street. Sold to the City of Portland in November of the same year for 42,000. Eventually replaced by the current Hawthorne Bridge in 1910.

properties.name: old Morrison/Mt. Tabor Line trolley tracks.
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesNarrow guage. Interesting because they run out of someone\'s driveway, across the street, and into the sidewalk of the southeast corner of Lone Fir Cemetary. Clearly, the street grid has shifted since this line was discontinued.

properties.name: old Steel Bridge (1889-c.1912)
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesBuilt by the Oregon Railway & Navigation Company. The lower deck was for the exclusive use of the railway company, and the upper for public and streetcar traffic. Replaced by current Steel Bridge circa 1912.

properties.name: old trolley tracks across the Burnside Bridge
properties.description: Posted by TinzeroesRoadwork on the Burnside Bridge in 2002 exposed old narrow-guage trolley tracks. Like, REALLY exposed them! This photo is by Mark Kavanagh of the Oregon Electric Railways Historical Society.
